Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that Disney has paid Tom Brady more times than any other professional athlete to say the phrase.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the number of times Tom Brady has been paid by Disney to say the phrase is the highest among all professional athletes, without providing any evidence or comparison.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for why Tom Brady has said the phrase multiple times, such as personal preference, contractual obligations, or other factors not related to Disney's payment.
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times in providing a clear and concise explanation of the specific instances and details of Disney's payment to Tom Brady.
Understate: The claim may understate the significance of the 2021 commercial, which not only highlighted the winning team's achievement but also recognized health care workers on the frontlines of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Disney started paying star NFL players to say the phrase on camera in 1987, suggesting that no player since then has completed the gig more times than Brady. However, the claim does not provide evidence or data to support this assertion.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance of Tom Brady's involvement in Disney's advertising gig by stating that he has been paid more times than any other professional athlete, without providing evidence or comparison.
